article.subject: Re: Worst Kickstarter Ever?
article.body:
Is it about time we start talking about the ridiculous thing "TSR" is doing?

So what happened is a Gygax brother let the trademark lapse on the TSR brand and it was immediately snatched up by people who run a local 'game museum' (I'm honestly not sure if this is much more than a hobby shop that specializes in collectable out of print stuff).

They announced that they planned to reprint some old RPG materials that Wizards of the Coast currently owns and sells in PDF form. Naturally Wizards sent them a C&D about that.

Well, they have decided that they want to bring a libel lawsuit against Wizards of the Coast on the grounds that Wizards of the Coast has said that Wizards does not approve of some problematic things in older D&D books.

- Remember, TSR has nothing at all to do with those D&D books, they are just random dudes who bought the trademark.

They've started an indiegogo with a flex goal, filed a legal claim, dropped it and vowed that they'll file another one, and thrown some minor tantrums in the comments section.

Support TSR against Wizards of the Coast

article.subject: Re: Worst Kickstarter Ever?
article.body:
odinsgrandson wrote:

- Remember, TSR has nothing at all to do with those D&D books, they are just random dudes who bought the trademark.

The indiegogo page contradicts the legal statement on the TSR website:
[q=https://tsr-hobbies.com/]Copyright © 2021 TSR Hobbies - All Rights Reserved.

The products contained on these pages include images, trademarks, artwork and other materials are owned and produced by TSR LLC and are not produced, endorsed or sponsored by or affiliated in any way with Wizards of the Coast, LLC or Hasbro, Inc.

If the products that TSR Hobbies holds the trademarks to are not affiliated in any way with WotC, then how can they claim that WotC is talking about TSR Hobbies products or staff in the Legacy Content Disclaimer? TSR Hobbies knew that the products owned by WotC have TSR branding on them. When WotC talks about the products WotC owns, TSR Hobbies can't suddenly claim that WotC is causing brand confusion. It would be like me calling my son Napoleon Bonaparte and then claiming damage is being done to my son when people speak ill of the dead Frenchman. I knew the confusion would happen because I caused the confusion.

It looks to me like they could have several goals here:

- Large companies often settle out of court by paying the plaintiff the money that they'd have to spend to defend themselves. That might be the goal here.

- TSR wants to imply continuity with the old TSR really hard. They seem interested in buying games with writing or development credits from one or another of the old TSR guys.

- TSR want to capitalize on old fans recently being angry at Wizards of the Coast over changes to the lore in response to criticism. They're trying to create Fox-News style outrage: saying anything was amiss with D&D books from the 1970s is an insult to D&D fans and you should all be mad!

I find it noteworthy that they already dropped their first case and that the excess money that they raise in their crowdfunding will go to building up their museum business. Their case does not have to hold any water for them to profit thereby.
